content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple (approximately 9-10) pieces of tissue, consistent with lymph nodes of various sizes. Many nodes appear dark purple (basophilic) and solid, suggesting either dense lymphoid tissue or complete replacement by tumor, which raises a high suspicion for metastatic disease. The normal lymph node architecture with distinct cortex and medulla is not clearly discernible at this magnification in most nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is located within one of the larger lymph nodes (the third from the left in the lower row). At low power, this node appears almost entirely replaced by dark cellular tissue, which is highly suspicious for metastasis. The purpose of zooming in is to examine the cellular morphology at high power to confirm or exclude the presence of metastatic carcinoma cells and to differentiate them from reactive lymphoid cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the second lymph node from the left. In the thumbnail view, this node does not have a uniform, solid appearance. It shows a mixture of dark, basophilic areas (likely residual lymphocytes) and lighter, more irregular areas. This heterogeneity is highly suspicious for infiltration and replacement of the normal lymphoid parenchyma by a metastatic process. I would examine this interface between the normal and abnormal-appearing tissue to confirm the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic review of all the submitted lymph nodes. This particular node, one of the smaller ones located in the upper-central part of the slide, appears highly cellular and darkly stained (basophilic) at low magnification. This appearance raises suspicion for either a reactive lymphoid process or, more importantly, infiltration by metastatic carcinoma. A closer look is necessary to examine the cellular architecture and cytology to make a definitive diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area, which is located in one of the central lymph nodes (approximately the 6th or 7th tissue section from the top left), because its low-power appearance is highly abnormal. The normal, dark, homogenous lymphoid architecture is replaced by irregular, paler, and cribriform-like spaces. This pattern is very suspicious for metastatic adenocarcinoma, and I need to zoom in to confirm the presence of malignant epithelial cells, assess their morphology (e.g., glandular, mucinous), and evaluate the extent of tumor infiltration versus residual lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of one of the lymph nodes located in the bottom row (the second from the right). This node appears to be largely replaced by tumor. The specific area of interest is the interface between the lymph node capsule and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. The purpose of this examination is to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the adjacent fatty tissue. ENE is a critical adverse prognostic factor that must be reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on the second lymph node from the top. I zoomed into this specific area because there is a subtle change in color and texture at the edge of the main lymphoid aggregate, in the subcapsular region. This area appears slightly paler and more disorganized than the surrounding monotonous dark blue lymphocytes. The subcapsular sinus is the first place metastatic cells often deposit, so any irregularity in this location is highly suspicious and requires high-magnification evaluation to differentiate between benign reactive changes (like sinus histiocytosis) and malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is one of the lymph nodes that appears abnormal at low magnification. This specific node (the second from the top right) is markedly hypercellular and basophilic, lacking the typical architecture of a benign lymph node (which would show distinct follicles and sinuses). This solid, dark-blue appearance is highly suspicious for complete effacement of the node by a cellular process, such as metastatic carcinoma or lymphoma. A systematic examination of all submitted lymph nodes is necessary, and this one is a high-priority area to investigate due to its suspicious features. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node. The green box is placed on the periphery of the third lymph node from the top on the right side. This specific location corresponds to the subcapsular sinus, which is the initial site where metastatic cells arriving via lymphatic vessels would deposit. It is a critical and high-yield area to scrutinize for even small clusters of tumor cells (micrometastases), making it a standard starting point for evaluating a lymph node for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see dense sheets of small, round, dark-staining cells with scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. There are large, irregularly shaped, clear-to-pink spaces that represent markedly dilated sinuses. These sinuses contain eosinophilic proteinaceous fluid (lymph) and scattered red blood cells. I do not see the characteristic features of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as malignant glands, nests of large atypical epithelial cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node showing prominent sinus histiocytosis and hemorrhage, rather than a positive node for metastasis. This finding would be considered negative for malignancy in this specific field of view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, there is a clear demarcation between two tissue types. There are sheets of small, dark lymphocytes, which are residual from the original lymph node. Infiltrating and replacing this lymphoid tissue are irregular nests and glandular structures composed of larger, pleomorphic cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and enlarged, vesicular nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the parenchyma of a lymph node being infiltrated by malignant cells. There are clusters and nests of atypical epithelial cells with large, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. These cells are forming irregular glandular or cribriform structures, which are classic features of adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are seen expanding the subcapsular and medullary sinuses. The surrounding native lymphoid tissue, composed of small, mature lymphocytes, serves as a stark contrast. My impression is that this is a lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming it as a positive lymph node (pN+).
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see extensive replacement of the normal lymph node parenchyma. The most striking feature is the presence of large, acellular-appearing pools of pale pink/basophilic material, which is extracellular mucin. Floating within these mucin pools are small clusters and strips of atypical epithelial cells. These cells have enlarged, hyperchromatic, and irregular nuclei. There are also aggregates of residual lymphoid tissue, seen as dense collections of small dark blue lymphocytes. My impression is definitive for metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma involving this lymph node. The node is unequivocally positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see metastatic adenocarcinoma, characterized by poorly formed glands and infiltrating tumor cells at the top of the image. This tumor is seen breaching the fibrous lymph node capsule (the pink band of connective tissue in the middle). There are clear nests of malignant cells extending beyond the capsule into the perinodal adipose tissue below. There is also an associated inflammatory response. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with unequivocal extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I see a distinct population of atypical cells located within what appears to be a dilated lymphatic sinus. These cells are different from the surrounding small, dark lymphocytes. They are larger, arranged in a loosely cohesive cluster, and possess more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and enlarged, irregular, hyperchromatic to vesicular nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The presence of this distinct cluster of malignant epithelial cells within the lymph node parenchyma confirms that this is a positive lymph node (i.e., contains metastatic cancer).
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a lymph node that is almost completely replaced by a dense, solid infiltrate of tumor cells. The cells are relatively monotonous, small to medium in size, with very scant cytoplasm, giving a 'small round blue cell' appearance. The nuclei are round to oval, hyperchromatic with a stippled or 'salt-and-pepper' chromatin pattern, and show significant nuclear molding (where nuclei are compressed and conform to the shapes of adjacent nuclei). These features are classic for a high-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma, specifically small cell carcinoma. This is a positive lymph node with metastatic carcinoma. The morphology is not that of a typical colorectal adenocarcinoma, which would prompt further investigation of the primary tumor for a neuroendocrine component.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I can clearly see the edge of the lymph node. On the right is the dense, normal-appearing lymphoid parenchyma composed of small, dark lymphocytes. On the left is the subcapsular sinus, a lymphatic space just beneath the fibrous capsule. Within these dilated sinusoids, there are several clusters of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and exhibit nuclear atypia (irregular shapes, hyperchromasia). These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node, with tumor cells present in the subcapsular sinus.
